Dr. Merlin knows this too well, her voice rising in protest when the weight of too much information bears down, strangling the narrative.

The truth is, exposition is a fickle companion.

Readers, wise and seasoned, know the adage: "Show, don't tell." Yet still, the lure of lengthy passages pulls even the best into its grip, where stories derail or drown in abundance. Exposition whispers in a writer's ear, urging them to lay bare the history, to rush through the mundane, to reach the heart of the tale. It is not unlike the fiend upon the shoulder, coaxing the author to divulge every trivial detail of each character's past.

But exposition is the telling of tales, the recounting of events in words that are too plain. In film, it is the monologue, the character laying out the tale like an ancient mariner's lament. In the realm of fiction, it is the author who speaks.

Suppose you read of a heroine who met her beloved at a certain time, in a certain place; they were wed in grandeur, and her husband's life was snuffed out before her eyes. Would you expect this tale to be spun in a mere two pages, their voices scarcely heard? Surely not. An author must delve into the husband's soul, his words and deeds a testament to his love, while the heroine, in her own way, reflects the change and richness he brought to her life. When she mourns, you mourn with her; her grief becomes yours, drawing you closer to her heart.

In essence, the tale demands more than the bare bones of "They met, they married, he died."

Writers must breathe life into the narrative, even when the urge to gloss over details beckons. Perhaps there is a new character, a man whose past is a tapestry of Air Force days, a gas station night manager's life, two marriages left behind, childless, with dreams of owning the station and a penchant for fishing. Once, he had Eggs Benedict for breakfast.

The dawn broke over Columbus, Ohio, and the first murmurings of the day came through the flickering screen, the news of the world carried forth by NBC 4. There was a man, his name Shad Hostettler, from Ashley, Ohio, who had turned the blade upon his own. His wife's name left unsaid, as if her silence was her own testament. They showed his likeness, a visage of malice, the eyes of a man who knew too well the darkness within. The tale was brief, a scant two minutes of time, a story still unfolding, yet it was enough. Enough for the world to know of the evil that walked among them.

Then came the story of Travis Buyers, a youth of eighteen years, his life hanging by a thread in the Sharon Woods, the morning's shadow upon him. No names save his own, no arrests, no suspects in the wind. The SWAT team prowling the scene like hounds in the night, their search fruitless as yet. The tale told quick and gone, the brevity of it a whisper of the world’s indifference, for he was a black man in a black neighborhood. A truth as old as time, that the world turns slower for those of darkness, a truth that cuts deeper than any blade.

There was a gunshot, a bullet that found its mark in the Med-Flight helicopter, a .22 caliber reminder of the world’s capriciousness. They spoke of where it might have happened, Crime-Stoppers offering riches for the name of the one who pulled the trigger. Five thousand pieces of silver for justice.

The skies were to weep come afternoon, the storms a promise of the day, the temperatures to cling to the low eighties, a respite of sorts. The weatherman’s voice a siren’s call to keep watching, to stay tuned for the storm to break.

And then a robbery on Clime Road, a man cloaked in darkness, a hoodie drawn against the world. They spoke of him, his skin dark as the night, his height and weight a litany of his form, the words lingering longer than they ought, as if his color was the crime itself.

Rene Rodriguez, a name spoken with disdain, a drug kingpin from Texas, his empire of marijuana stretching to Ohio. They spoke of his sentence, 300 months, the years wrapped in numbers that seemed to stretch further than the truth. Hispanic, they said, a man marked by his heritage, though it mattered not. The world cares little for such things when it casts its judgment.

And so the stories were told, the tales of the day laid bare, the world turning still, indifferent to the lives it held in its grasp.

In the realm of financial instruments, the ETF stands like a lone sentinel upon the plains. An exchange traded fund, it is, crafted to mirror the ebb and flow of an index, a commodity, or perhaps a basket of assets akin to an index fund, yet possessed of a singular flexibility, for it moves upon the exchange as a stock might. The ETF offers the broad sweep of diversification found in an index, yet retains the singular charm of stock ownership, granting the ability to sell short, to buy on margin, to hold in one's hand as few as a single share. Though these attributes glisten with the allure of promise, their expense ratios remain modest, far beneath the weight of the common mutual fund. Yet, not all is without cost, for a commission is the toll exacted upon any trade, as if one were dealing in the stocks of old. 

The breadth of ETFs is wide, a tapestry of funds unfurled across the market. And in this, the savvy traveler in the world of finance must ever question, must ever seek if the proclaimed benefits, such as diversification, stand true in the harsh light of scrutiny, and to what extent they hold. Our endeavor here is to examine the ETF known as IHF, to lay it against those top ten holdings that form its backbone, to weigh if the single ETF stands in the light cast by a diversified portfolio of those ten stocks, and if there be configurations yet untried that might yield an optimal balance, a sharper return.

In this undertaking, the burden of examining each holding in its entirety would be a cumbersome beast indeed. Thus, we consider only the top ten, which account for 63.58% of the ETF’s assets. Below lie the top 10 holdings, each a piece of the whole.

To grasp how these ten stocks serve as the face of the ETF IHF, we may turn to the current % of assets, brought to a unity of 100%, and from this, derive the contributions of each stock to the Beta and Return of a portfolio composed solely of these ten, each in the measure the ETF has ordained through its holdings. The calculus of Beta and return is laid bare in the chart below.

From the figures, one sees clearly that a portfolio with but the top ten holdings boasts a return 6.11% greater than the ETF, a rise of 16% in returns. It is also clear that the Beta of these ten is .12 lower than the ETF in its entirety. The findings thus suggest that a portfolio trimmed to these ten holdings might yield a greater return with diminished Beta. Yet, there remains the whisper of doubt, the question if the means of these two portfolios stand apart, truly distinct from one another.

To probe this matter, to discern if these portfolios are as different as they seem, we turn to the standard deviation of each stock among the top ten, each brought to the same measure of 100%, to compare their collective standard deviation to that of the ETF IHF.

In the cold breath of winter, the numbers fell away like leaves from a dying tree. A campus in New England, the air biting and cruel, saw the logs of commuters dwindle in the third month, a sharp decline that seemed to echo the silent halls and empty paths where once footsteps trod. December, the month where the world turns inward, brought with it final flurries of schoolwork, grades, and the weight of a year closing. The days slipped away, and with them the memory of the commuter log, lost amidst the rush and the hush of the holiday's onset. A break, a pause in the cycle, where the students and faculty vanished into the month-long void, leaving the campus hushed in their absence. 

The spring would come, as it always does, late in January, when the world begins to thaw and life resumes its relentless march. Yet, February lay like a shadow, unexplained in its emptiness, a mystery of missing numbers. Perhaps it was the nature of things, the way a fire burns brightest at the start and then fades to embers, that saw this project wane. In March, there came a reckoning, a challenge to stir the ashes—Carpool Challenge Week—a desperate bid to breathe life once more into what had nearly faded. And indeed, the logs rose again, a testament to the struggle against the inevitable, against the ebb of engagement and the fickle nature of interest.

Yet there lay another struggle in this, one that ran deeper than mere numbers. The road calls with its freedom, its independence, the car a symbol of autonomy deeply rooted in the soul of the people. To tempt them away, to lure them to another path, required more than mere entreaties. Prizes were offered, tokens of encouragement: gift certificates, small treasures for local indulgences. But what if there had been more? A bicycle, a hybrid, an electric car—a dream to chase, a spark to ignite the drifting interest. The prizes remained static, unchanged through the journey, but had they grown, had they offered more, perhaps the tide would have turned in December, perhaps January would not have felt so desolate. The thought lingers, the what-ifs dance in the shadows, and one can only wonder what might have been.

In the quiet corridors of the Library of Congress, I came upon a collection of early Edison films, a trove of moving pictures that seemed to whisper of a time long vanished. Among them, the trick films held my attention, fifteen in number, spanning the years 1895 to 1901. These were not merely films but illusions spun from the loom of creative editing, each frame a sleight of hand. My study lingered there, tracing the poetic form of these cinematic conjurings, noting the divergences that marked the later reels with a kind of evolutionary boldness. At the turn of the century, the trick film sat bound within its stage, framed by the stoic proscenium, the camera still as stone, capturing the world in long and medium shots, adhering to the creed of one shot equating to one film. Yet, some dared to defy this rigid doctrine, weaving in the novelty of multiple shots.

The films were held in a shared embrace by their setting—a fixed interior, a proscenium view that rooted its essence in the theater, in the flickering world of vaudeville and magic shows. The camera, a sentinel in its place, did not stir to follow the dance of figures or objects. This immobility was a hallmark of the age, a tether to the theater's past, where the stage was the world entire. In these frames, the actors moved only side to side, a lateral ballet with no voyage toward the lens. Take, for instance, Uncle Josh in a Spooky Hotel (1900), where the performers entered from the right, tracing their paths along a horizontal script. Even as they slipped beyond the frame's edge, the camera remained steadfast.

The proscenium's gaze favored the long shot, occasionally bending to a medium, but never closer, never a whisper of the close-up. This was the theater's doing, a tradition where the audience beheld the whole, framed by the stage's borders. The actors, anchored in the middle ground, ventured no nearer, and so the close-up remained a stranger.

In the main, these early trick films played by the rule that one envisioned shot equaled a film, confining their stories to a minute's breath, shaped by the frames per second. This brevity curtailed the narrative ambition, the films becoming more akin to vaudeville's quick tricks—magic, vanishments, transformations—brief spectacles without a tale to tell. Yet, the notion of one shot in the viewer's eye was but an illusion; a single "shot" could be a tapestry of many, stitched together to conjure apparitions or make bodies vanish. Consider The Execution of Mary, Queen of Scots (1895), among the first of its kind. To the viewer, it seemed a seamless vision, but look closely and see where the physical shot with Mary's severed "head" takes its cue, a revelation in the guise of a singular shot.

In the old bones of the Gothic Novel lies a contradiction, an oxymoron of 'Old-New' as Ian Watt lays bare in his exploration of this literary breed. This Gothic form, both scorned and revered, accused of shallowness and celebrated for its terrible grandeur, took its first breath in Horace Walpole's The Castle of Otranto. Here was a weaving of the ancient with the so-called modern, a birthing of the proto-Gothic that forged a new tongue for telling tales. Walpole drew from the ancient stage, from the mimicry of the world in 'modern' narratives, to craft what he called "A Gothic Story." The genre stood draped in echoes of medieval stagecraft, of towering architecture, of old ways and rites. Even as The Castle of Otranto saw the light, 'gothic' was a word worn by many styles and eras, seen as relic or crude in the face of modern strides in society and letters. Yet in that meeting of theatrical Gothic with the new novel's form, where characters' minds lay bare to the reader, the Gothic endured, living and dying anew to readers far from its genesis.

One theme that wound tight through Gothic novels was chivalry. That medieval code, the shaping of a knight, found both echo and change in The Castle of Otranto. To those Gothic scribes, chivalry was a beacon, a symbol of brave and noble knights, a dream lost in the mire of their own times. Through chivalry's lens, the Gothic past became a golden age, a romantic ideal to mend the present. Walpole, caught in the storm of politics and shadowed by claims of injustice, perhaps saw in the Gothic age a purity lost to his own. This thought took shape in his characters, like Frederic, who bore the chivalric mantle. Before Frederic steps from the page, he is painted with the strokes of a bygone knight, a prince, scarred by tragedy, thought slain by infidels. This "gallant and courteous Knight" stands larger than life, a figure drawn in excess, a harbinger of the Gothic's future form.

In the ghostly corridors of commerce, where shadows of goods traverse the earth from the whispered wants of the customer through the raw sinews of creation, there lies the tale of supply chain management. Born in the year of nineteen hundred and eighty-two at the hands of Keith Oliver, a soul given to consulting, this tale speaks of the orchestration of needs and wills, of time and place, all to sate the hunger of the market with a cold efficiency. Six are the pillars that hold this spectral edifice aloft: production, supply, inventory, location, transportation, and information. It is upon these that the managers of business lay their weary hands to summon forth service to their kin, the customer.

Production, the first whisper in this chain of shadows, is the bedrock upon which all else is built. It is the questioner, asking when and where, why and how all must be wrought from the earth. The manager, a seer of sorts, peers into the market, that great oracle, to divine the desires of the masses. Once the runes of demand are cast and the market's heart revealed, decisions are made as to what shall be brought into the light and in what number. The where of it, the place of birthing, is chosen with care, the plant that shall nurture the goods to meet the demands and desires of the world. With place decided, the burdens of scheduling and the maintenance of the great machines fall upon the manager's shoulders. Each detail must be a thread in the tapestry, lest the whole unravel and precious time and gold be lost to the winds.

In the days when I labored under the roofs of Wal-Mart and Target, I saw these designs, these books of process, each a scripture of order from the garments worn by the worker to the rhythm of trucks arriving with their burdens. Such outlines bring a clarity where confusion might otherwise reign, a map through the labyrinth of commerce.

The second pillar of this shadowed realm is supply. Here lies the strategy, the decisions that shape the very bones of a facility, the alliances forged with other hands to strengthen the weave. A product may have many faces and many homes, each division with its own tools and craftsmen. It falls upon the manager to discern the best path, the best division for each task, or to seek the hands of others beyond their walls. It is velocity they seek, that swift dance of quality and adaptability, all while keeping the wolf of cost at bay.

Thus is the tale of supply chain management told, a tapestry of decisions and designs, where each move echoes through the halls of commerce, forever shaping the shadows upon the land.

In the vast tapestry of Victorian literature, the threads of detail and aristocratic focus weave a common pattern. Yet, in Oliver Twist and Wuthering Heights, the weave frays and twists into something other. Here lies mystery, a penchant for the bizarre, a departure from the expected that breathes depth into their characters, revealing souls laid bare by the winds of their peculiar worlds.

In the shadows of Oliver Twist, there lingers a passage where bewilderment reigns. "And now, hosts of bewildering and confusing ideas came crowding on his mind. He seemed to be still walking between Sikes and Crackit, who were angrily disputing: for the very words they said, sounded in his ears; and when he caught his own attention, … he found that he was talking to them…. Suddenly he started back at the report of fire arms; and there rose into the air loud cries and shouts; lights gleamed before his eyes, and all was noise and tumult, as some unseen hand bore him hurriedly away. Through all these rapid visions, there ran an undefined, uneasy consciousness of pain, which weared and tormented him incessantly.” (Dickens, 220)

Such dreams and waking nightmares cloak Oliver Twist in a shroud of enigma, revealing the boy's heartaches and the shadows that lurk around him. As Oliver revisits the moment of his shooting, reality bends to dreams, and in that bending, a truth emerges. The world around him, a maelstrom in which he is but a leaf, carries him without his will. The hallucinations of Sikes and Crackit echo through the fog of his mind, and the pain of his wound becomes a constant, a companion in fear rather than surprise. The question of whose hand guides this fate rises like smoke, for it is not Oliver's own. This incident is a testament to his powerlessness, his inability to wrest control from the grip of fate, even when life hangs by a thread. A whisper of defeat creeps into the narrative, the shadow of Fagin's influence casts long over the boy, carving acceptance from despair, dulling his will to fight. Else he might have struggled, if for nothing more than survival.

"The day passed off – day! There was no day; it was gone as soon as come – and night came on again; night so long, and yet so short; long in its dreadful silence and short in its fleeting hours.

In these pages, the day and night are as phantoms, slipping through the fingers, leaving the characters adrift in their wake. Such is the nature of this Victorian mystery, a departure into the unknown, where the heart is laid bare, and the soul finds its voice in the shadows of its time.

In the years gone by, I found myself bound in the duty of guiding young minds in the hours after school had ended. Small souls gathered there, each wrestling with their own particular trials in the realm of letters and numbers, but it was the written word where I found my own strength lay. There was a boy, Adrian, a lad no older than ten who found himself at odds with the act of reading. The letters on the page confounded him, some he pronounced as if they were old friends, others as though they were strangers he had never met. He was a child of Latino heritage, yet his English rolled off the tongue as naturally as if he were born to it. We stumbled through the morass of incomprehension until the day I crossed paths with his mother. She came like a shadow into the small room where I lingered with a few stragglers, my charges for the afternoon. The woman spoke only in her native Spanish, a tongue I knew but little of, yet we managed to bridge the chasm of language between us. It was then that the truth revealed itself with the weight of certainty: Adrian could read, but the English script was an unfamiliar terrain to him. Whether this revelation served to aid him I cannot say, but the hope remains that he finds himself on surer ground now.

This tale serves to illuminate the chasm that exists in the schools, particularly in a place such as California, where tongues are as varied as the colors of the sky at dusk. It is a reminder that the struggle with language is often hidden beneath the surface, that even a child whose speech flows with ease may find the written word a formidable adversary. The question that arises is what course to chart from here? For Adrian, it was a matter of guiding him through the intricacies of English pronunciation and the alphabet. Yet for the multitude who scarcely know English, the journey is fraught with greater complexity. The answer is not singular or simple. The dual language system, immersion in the mainstream, private guides, classes for those learning English as a second tongue—none alone can surmount this barrier. The path lies in the weaving together of all these threads.

The dual language system holds promise, not only for those whose first breath was in Spanish but for all children. "Children in two-way bilingual education programs have been found to outperform their peers academically," the words echoing like a prophecy. There is fear and whisperings that such endeavors squander resources, that the many will find no gain. But these are lies. Were we to embrace such methods as the rule and not the exception, all would reap the harvest. But how to proceed? Shall we decree that all who teach must speak in two tongues? No, that is a dream too far. Yet, what hinders us from bringing forth aides and tutors, those who walk in both worlds and can guide others across the divide?

From the time we're young, they tell us there's something grander than us, something beyond the grasp of our understanding. Some go to Sunday school, others to Temple, and some dig deep within themselves for answers. Many of us take up the faiths handed down by our kin. Yet, there are those who turn their backs entirely, denying anything exists beyond their own narrow world. We might cling to one set of beliefs only to later cast them aside for another. Whatever path we tread, we're seeking to carve out a piece of who we are through our own spiritual lenses. We search for a beacon in the darkness to guide us from the shadows into the light.

"A cardinal," my father said when I asked him his favored bird. We sat on the front porch, the rain beating a rhythm on the tin roof above, both of us with cigarettes in hand. The gutters spilled over, drowning the plants lined up along the porch's edge. He gazed out into the rain, a look that seemed part searching, part lost in memory. He'd grown frail in those past months, his clothes hanging loose from his frame. His hair, too, had thinned, more sparse than I remembered. His eyes stayed fixed on the rain, avoiding mine. A loneliness settled in, a fear that kept words trapped inside, for speaking them might make it all too real. I hugged him, moved my chair closer, and joined him in staring into the June twilight rain.

My father left this world in December, five days after I turned twenty-two. The chemo and radiation didn't ease his pain but stretched his days past what the doctors had foreseen. What worth was there in suffering longer, I couldn't say. What kind of God would allow this, I wondered. Alone in the night, I whispered no prayers. If God was there, I figured He'd stopped listening long ago.

I couldn't bring myself to watch him slip from this life to the next. So I didn't. I couldn't bear witness to the end of the life that gave me mine. I wanted to remember him by how he lived, not how he died. Besides, I knew him better than they did, better than his kin, and I knew he wouldn't want his only child to bear witness to his end. I curled up in bed, buried myself there for three days, waiting for the news.

No call ever came.

In the time when the land lay unburdened by the weight of history, John Taylor of Caroline stood as a sentinel of Republicanism, carved from the very soil he tilled. An agrarian by heart and trade, his brief foray into the realm of politics left a mark of resolute conviction on the pages of governance—a voice that rang clear in the defense of the individual's liberty and the rights of man against the encroaching tide of authority. His allegiance to the agrarian creed shaped his thoughts like the furrowed lines of the earth, bearing seeds that would sprout opinions on sovereignty, the Constitution, and the judiciary, each one tethered to the notion of a pastoral ideal.

Taylor saw in the nascent United States a canvas unmarked by the hands of tradition, a place where the architects of government could craft something pure and untamed—a self-governing Eden. He held firm to the belief in natural rights, those intrinsic to the human spirit, each one knotted to the other, a tapestry that would unravel if even one thread was pulled. Such rights, he declared, must remain beyond government's grasp, for in the untamed state of nature, it was the cunning and the strong who reaped the spoils. But in civilization, this must not be so.

To forge this utopia, Taylor reckoned, a government must be wrought that embraces the dual nature of man—his capacity for both light and shadow. To him, the morals of government were but a reflection of man's own virtues and sins. He spoke of good principles, those that safeguarded the sanctity of private property, nurtured the land, and fended off the specter of capitalism. A government grounded in such principles could endure, he argued, even under the sway of self-interest, that perpetual engine of human endeavor, so long as it did not gnaw at the foundations of the common good to fatten itself upon others. A vigilant government was the bulwark against man's innate darkness, ever watchful to prevent the taint of vile principles.

In chorus with his fellow Republicans, Taylor demanded a Constitution interpreted not loosely but with the precision of a craftsman's hand. He envisioned a Federal government circumscribed by the explicit words of that sacred text, wary of the expansive beast that might grow fat and tyrannical. Yet, he warned of the perils in an interpretation devoid of the framers' intent, for such a path was fertile ground for corruption. In his eyes, the Declaration of Independence stood as the true testament of the Union, a covenant that spoke of a confederacy of sovereign states, not a singular nation bound by fetters unseen.

He stood there, eyes cast down, the world narrowing to the scene before him, yet his mind remained a vast blank canvas. The gaze was steady, devoid of emotion, a practiced detachment that absorbed every detail without assigning meaning or context. Thoughts came and went, ephemeral whispers, barely settling before they vanished, leaving behind the purity of perception untainted by conscious reflection.

Once, an artist he knew had suggested a book, a tome called The New Drawing on the Right Side of the Brain, an offering that promised to unlock the mysteries of form and line. Since childhood, a desire to capture the world in graphite and charcoal had lingered within him. The book spoke of framing, of taking a world too intricate to grasp and reducing it to something manageable—a bowl of fruit, isolated from the chaos of kitchen and dining room.

Yet, as he stood, eyes fixed on the vessel before him, the mental frame eluded him. Overwhelmed, he could do nothing but stand in silent testament to the spectacle laid out. Like Picasso lost in blue or Monet awash in green, he stood on the cusp of an artistic revelation—his own Work in Brown.

His fingers, delicate in their task, found the tool of his craft. Muscles tensed and released, guiding his hand in fluid arcs, a dancer's grace in the execution of necessity. The water churned, a crystalline ballet, carrying away fragments of the scene. Once more, his hand found the lever, a nervous urgency propelling the motion, but the obstinate form resisted, anchored to the porcelain depths.

He stood, mop in hand, feet planted as if to weather a storm, the green tie a noose around his neck. A frown creased his brow as he regarded the offensive castoff, a message of sorts from those who frequented the Rite Aid restrooms, a testament to the labors of those who cleaned. After several attempts, each one a meditation on futility, his hand reached to the side, grasping the end of the toilet paper, wrapping it thickly around his fingers until it became a crude glove. 

He straightened, then bent once more, the hand descending into the bowl with the slow inevitability of a ritual, like a pilgrim's hand reaching into fire for a sacred relic.

In the shadowed corridors of consequence young lives are snuffed out behind the wheel. Factors converge in a grim symphony, a deadly vector for the freshest faces of American roads. The National Institutes of Health lay bare the truth that the adolescent mind is a realm unprepared for the dark ballet of driving. Inexperience lies coiled at the heart of it, a serpent in the garden, birthing not only fatal crashes but a litany of rollovers, reckless speed, and the inevitable veering from the road's edge. 

Amongst their peers they fare worse, as any soul with a mote of sense might reckon they would, wandering in packs as is their wont. The Southern California Injury Prevention Research Center has charted the link between the age of those carried and the frequency of their misfortune on the asphalt. 

California and her sister states have tried to weave a net of safety, granting only provisional licenses that bind the hands of the young, setting limits on the hours they may roam and forbidding the carriage of other minors. Yet such measures are but stopgaps, mere patches on a yawn of an abyss. The youngest among us are, by every accounting of statistical markers, ill-equipped to wield the weight of such responsibility. 

Marvin Zuckerman, a psychologist who peers into the workings of the young mind, posits even eighteen years is too tender for a regular license to drive. In USA Today, Zuckerman’s research speaks of a common lust among those not yet nineteen or twenty, a hunger for the thrill of risk. It stands to reason then, that driving should be delayed, the itch of thrill-seeking allowed to wane. 

If we persist in issuing licenses to these young fledglings, the roads will continue to drink deep of their blood, and the toll will rise to towering heights. By the year of 2010, the offspring of the Baby Boomers will be of age to grip the wheel and a legion of new teen drivers will unfurl upon the highways. 

Legislation to address this is a simple enough affair. Let the schools keep to their classrooms, teaching the ways of the road, but let no one under eighteen command a vehicle. A provisional permit, yes, before a full license, and let there be a reckoning of hours spent learning the craft behind the wheel. The number of hours, a figure drawn from the states’ own books, like California with its six hours of direct training and fifty hours in the company of an adult. The grim ledger of teen driving stretches across this land, and thus a uniform national law seems a reasonable means, a shield to guard the youth from themselves. Such legislation is no new dawn, but perhaps it is a lantern in the dark.

In the quiet reaches of the mind where sound is meant to find its way, there lies a disorder, a tangled skein of miscommunication. Central Auditory Processing Disorder, they call it. Or Auditory Processing Disorder if you prefer your terms less ensnaring. It's a discord in the brain's symphony, where the central nervous system fails to harmonize the notes that wander in from the outside world. A condition not of the ear but of the understanding, where the music heard does not translate to the music felt.

The disorder's tale begins in the mid-century past, a time when children with voices trapped within sought release. They called it auditory imperception then, a name as cumbersome as the disorder itself. Italian minds—Bocca, Calearo, Cassinari—cast their nets wide over the mystery in 1954, and by '61, Kimura introduced a new lens, dichotic testing, a means to unravel the physiology of perception. The story unfolded further in '77, when minds gathered to press forward the understanding of children thus afflicted.

In its myriad manifestations, CAPD whispers confusion into the ear. A person may find themselves adrift in spaces where sounds drift aimlessly, unable to anchor their source. Discrimination is a task unfit for such ears, as the cacophony of the world layers itself indistinguishably. Patterns in sound become enigmatic, speech loses its tonal depth, sarcasm slips unnoticed beneath the waves of conversation. Sounds overlap, one masking the other, and the sequence of auditory events becomes as indecipherable as an ancient script.

Diagnosis, elusive as it is, requires a tapestry of observation and testing. Audiologists, speech-language pathologists, psychologists—they all take their turns at unraveling the disorder's mystery. They watch, they listen, they question. But no single tool exists, no definitive test to hold the truth aloft. Instead, they challenge the ears with a multitude of sounds, seeking the patterns hidden within the chaos. Advanced methods probe deeper, recording the echoes within and measuring the soul's response to its own dissonance.

In this world of sound and silence, the disorder remains a shadow, its cause a whisper lost on the wind. But in the pursuit of understanding, there is hope, a light to guide those who find themselves adrift in a sea of sound, searching for the shore.

In the pursuit of an education in social work, I find myself drawn along a path leading to the Division of Family and Children Services, where I aim to cast a light for children shadowed by abuse and neglect, and to offer solace to families adrift in turmoil. The values I bring to this field are not mere attributes but the very bedrock of my being: service, respect, an ethical compass, and a dedication to fostering relationships and honing my craft to remain steadfast and competent. These are not simply the tenets of social work; they are the marrow of my own soul.

There was always a yearning within me to aid others, yet the path was shrouded in uncertainty. Through the corridors of high school and college, I saw many souls lost to the fog of denial, some seeking refuge in ways less than ideal. Witnessing such trials, I embarked on a journey to earn a Bachelor’s degree in Psychology. Still, the road ahead lay obscured, and so I paused after stepping forth from Piedmont College in 2009. That summer, under a sun that bore witness, I visited a friend and met a boy of sixteen, his form tense upon her couch. He had come seeking refuge from an existence marred by abusive parents. The next day, the law was summoned to his home, and I went there, driven by a need to help. Speaking to the officers, I shared my concerns, and they listened as I told them of my education. They asked if I might speak with the parents. Their words were laced with unease, painting their son as a manipulator who sought intervention for what they claimed were mere trifles. It was in this moment, amidst the tangled truths and half-lies, that I realized my calling lay in social work, to aid those ensnared by such “simple” disputes.

Justice, too, holds its place among my values. As a society, we raise a lament for the lost yet cling to traditions that stifle the very individuality we claim to cherish. If we mourn the lost, why do we chase sameness? I have never found comfort in such confines. Throughout my days in high school and college, I stood against the tide of social injustice: coloring my hair against convention, clothing myself in garments that sang of my spirit, piercing beyond the norm, joining the GSBA to declare my stance, fighting against the specters of racism and discrimination whenever they reared their heads. I believe in justice's cause, and I will continue to champion it against the dark.

In the gloom of the scholarly inquiry, there lies the study of insomnia, the affliction that haunts the night with its silent pallor, and the paper before us seeks to unravel its mysteries through the lenses of the Biological and Sociocultural models. The biological model, with its roots deep in the hereditary soil, examines the genetic tapestry and medical nuances woven into the fabric of health. Meanwhile, the Sociocultural models cast their gaze upon the worldly bonds of environment, race, ethnicity, and the stark demarcations of demographic and socioeconomic boundaries. In this review, the shroud is lifted from insomnia as these models are laid bare, each piece of research dissected to illuminate the models, and then scrutinized, their strengths and frailties laid open to the world.

The realm of sleep, where disorders creep unseen, can be divided into primary sleep disorders, those tied to mental disquiet, and those born of other maladies. Within the primary lies Dyssomnias and Parasomnias, while disorders linked to mental discord trace back to Axis I or Axis II afflictions. Still others rise from medical tribulations or the shadow of substances. The Dyssomnias—Primary Insomnia, Primary Hypersomnia, Narcolepsy, and others—stand as sentinels of disrupted slumber, each with its tale of woe. Primary Insomnia, the thief of rest, and Primary Hypersomnia, the relentless sleep, both linger for no less than a month. Narcolepsy, with its specters of cataplexy and automatic REM, joins them in this dance of unrest. While Dyssomnias battle with the onset and maintenance of sleep, Parasomnias arise from behavioral and physiological anomalies, with nightmares and terrors as their harbingers. The disorders bound to mental discord, tied to Axis I or II, weave a different story. This review, however, turns its focus to insomnia, a solitary beacon amid the primary sleep disorders, as it relates to the biological and sociocultural realms.

In the biological sphere, the whispers of genes and the echoes of heredity intertwine with the physiological chorus of sleep disorders. Within the hypothalamic shadows, neurons harboring orexin hold the reins of slumber and wakefulness. A study, with mice as its earthly avatars, discovered phenotypic GABAB receptors on these orexin neurons, guardians of sleep and wake states. The GABAA receptor, when called to arms, ushers in sleep, yet if silenced, it quells anxiety and beckons rest. Baclofen, the GABAB agonist, stretched the hours of sleep (Matsuki et al., 2009). These findings, though drawn from the world of mice, hint at echoes in the human realm, whispering of a genetic and environmental foundation for the GABAB receptor. A flaw or absence in this receptor might mar one's ability to grasp sleep's embrace without aid. The sociocultural echoes of this study suggest that an inherited phenotype could dictate the dance of sleep, and any disruption in the receptor's song would ripple through life's tapestry, casting shadows on school, work, and the mundane tasks that require unwavering focus.

He'd been wandering the paths of University Park now for what seemed like an eternity, though in truth it was but two and a half years, or four and a half semesters if one counted by the calendar's reckoning. In those early days, finding his way from place to place had been a trial, an ordeal of distance and weather. His first year had seen him lodged in a dormitory at the far eastern edge of the campus, beyond which lay only the stadium and the Bryce Jordan Center, great monuments in the emptiness. From his sanctuary in Stuart Hall, the journey to places like Willard building, set near the heart of the campus, stretched to an ungodly twenty-five minutes on foot, the trek made worse by the capricious weather that seemed to haunt State College.

He'd spoken with those who'd come before, alumni not much older than himself, who spoke of a time when the halls in the east were cut off from the rest of the world by vast barren lands. Those lands were now swallowed by sports fields, grand edifices like the new Creamery, and a health services building, all encircled by a sprawl of apartments. As the campus swelled and spread, so too did the difficulty of traversing it. The question that loomed like a shadow was how best to navigate this ever-growing expanse. The answer, simple yet profound, lay in the humble bicycle. Yet a bike alone was not enough; it needed the will of the riders and a campus molded to their needs.

He'd spoken with a friend, one who had returned to cycling after a long absence. His friend marveled at why he had ever given it up. "Bikes are great," he'd said, "for a few years it wasn’t cool to ride a bike, but it’s the only way to get around." In his words lay a truth as clear as the morning sun. Bicycling, in its simplicity, was the most efficient path. A bowl of oatmeal and the push of the legs could carry a soul thirty miles or more. Living off campus now, as far-flung as any dormitory, he'd come to see the wisdom in owning a bike. Each day he faced the prospect of reaching the Thomas building, a place that by foot would consume a quarter of an hour or more. Yet astride his bike, the wind in his face, he could reach it in five if he rode with purpose. The road that beckoned, Pollock Road, was the most direct route, though not without its challenges. Walking had its merits, but time was a commodity he could not afford to waste. Without his bike, the walk to Thomas would steal away thirty or forty minutes from each day, amounting to more than two and a half hours of lost time each week. Time he could not spare, for life was a tapestry of classes and appointments and other obligations that demanded his presence. He knew then, as he knew now, that the bicycle was not merely a means to an end, but a companion on this journey through the wilderness of education.

In the pages of Brave New World, Aldous Huxley crafts a vision where the looming shadow of technology and the capitalist scaffold it rests upon cast a pall over humanity. The world he spins is one where the individual is subsumed into the mass, where the pursuit of fleeting happiness is the creed learned from the cradle. The people, mere pawns in a grander scheme, are held in thrall by a singular doctrine decreed by the World Controller. Through the prism of Marxist theism, one discerns Huxley's lurking doubts about the paths these systems have hewn. Words like homogeny and reification, borrowed from Marxist discourse, underscore the novel's critique of the nascent economic order of Huxley's era.

Capitalism is laid bare through the lens of false consciousness, a Marxist concept. The common folk, their eyes blindfolded to the true ties that bind them to other classes, chase after their own gain, oblivious to the strings that control them. This ideological dominance over the proletariat and the everyday laborer is starkly portrayed in the conditioning of Brave New World's denizens. The lower echelons, the Deltas and Gammas, move through life without volition; their slumbering minds echo with the chants of consumption and indulgence, all orchestrated by the World Controller. Hegemony, the total domination of social classes by a separate few, is evident here. The lower classes, blissfully ignorant, invest in an ideology that props up the very structure that enslaves them—capitalism and consumerism. The upper echelons, the Alphas and Betas, possess the awareness but seldom act, save for a few like Bernard who stir against their chains. The interplay of these social strata offers a window into capitalism's perceived yoke.

In this brave new world, true connections between souls are but a mirage. Characters meld into a faceless throng, even those of prominence, their depths unexplored. Perhaps Huxley whispers of a world where technology and capitalism, hand in hand, strip away man's will and voice. Love is a ghost, emotions muted to dull hums; interactions are but surface ripples, evident in the men’s idle prattle about women’s physical traits, the pneumatic allure, and the women’s unabashed recounting of their liaisons. The classes' contentment with their station speaks to the socioeconomic chains of capitalism. Their unwavering adherence to their roles mirrors Marxist reflections on the proletariat, lulled into believing their supremacy as long as they consume, obey, and march in step with their fellows.

Four years past, I found myself in a course on Islam at CBC, a place of learning where discourse ran hot like the sands of some ancient desert. The question that flared bright among us was whether Islam bore hostility in its heart. This inquiry feels ever more pressing in the shadow of years since the towers fell. I have watched the tides of media shift from angered waves casting Islam in shadow to a strange tide of acceptance in this land of ours. In those days of 2001, could we have imagined a man named Barack Obama, with whispers of Muslim lineage, rising to seek the mantle of leadership?

The tale of the Prophet, it calls to me with its contradictions. What history tells of Muhammad seems at odds with the portrait painted in the pages of his life. I had been taught that Muhammad was a man who wielded faith as a weapon, subduing tribes beneath the banner of Islam. Yet the biography speaks of a martyr, a figure misunderstood and humble, gathering followers by truth alone. They came to him, it says, drawn by the light of his teachings.

And there are echoes here of another story, of Jesus and the miracles wrought in his time. The Prophet, it is said, took mutton and milk, multiplying them to feed forty souls. Such tales, penned to show Muhammad as a humble prophet of miracles, seem to me a theft of the divine story of Christ. It is as if they cloak the life of Jesus in the garb of another, seeking to borrow the light of his deeds.

The biography spins many tales of conversion, of souls turning to Islam by their own sight. Yet these are stories told through layers of voices, each a whisper from another's lips. This chain of hearsay, meant to lend truth, leaves me uneasy. It casts doubt upon the tale, like shadows on a moonlit path.

What gnaws at me most is the elevation of Muhammad to a pedestal of sainthood. They speak of him as gentle, wise, and humble. But history's voice tells of a different man, of a rise to power marked not by gentleness but by force. I wonder if those who follow him now know the true story that lies beneath the sands of time.

In the passage of time, the teachings of Jesus seemed to vanish like whispers in a storm, left behind as the tides of Christian thought surged forth. As one gazes upon the sprawling canvas of history, a picture emerges of a faith that has drifted from its moorings, its origins obscured by the dust of ages. Our present world, with its burgeoning awareness and fervent march toward progress, stands in stark contrast. Tradition clings to the hearts of some, those who guard their inherited truths with unyielding fervor. Yet, their numbers may not suffice to sway the collective course. Among believers, a profound historical consciousness will awaken in the years to come. A restless hunger will arise to peel away the layers of doctrine accreted over time, to uncover the essence of what the Nazarene intended. It may span decades or centuries, but the tide will turn inexorably. A great unwinding will occur in the annals of Christian history, a reversion to the wellspring of its inception. A movement will gather strength, stripping away the accumulated dogmas as if time itself were reversing, leaving only the purest vision of what Jesus imparted to humanity, unmarred by the claims of later thinkers. When this wave sweeps through the lands of America and Europe, drawing multitudes into its embrace, the church will remain, a steadfast beacon to guide the way. Yet, as theological time rewinds, the vast diversity that has flourished within Christendom will yield to a growing unity of belief and practice. Where once divisions lay between regions, denominations, and sects, there will emerge a tapestry of shared convictions. History is replete with reversals of fortune. Recall how Christians, once hunted and reviled by the Roman Empire, later saw that empire don the mantle of their faith. Our nation has journeyed from the bondage of African-American slavery to the heights of African-American leadership. The coming reversion will unfold within the realm of Christianity, unraveling history's tapestry to seek its source, diminishing diversity in the process. It is vital to recognize that this transformation will hinge on a reading of Jesus' words as metaphor, not as literal decree. What, then, transpired since the days of Jesus? If we cast our gaze far enough back, we find only Judaism, the theological seedbed from which Christianity sprang forth. Monotheism, the perception of a divinely revealed faith, and the authority of Hebrew scriptures formed the bedrock by the time Rome laid its hand upon Jerusalem in 63 B.C.E. Yet, even among the Jews, unity was scarce. They fractured into Sadducees, Pharisees, Essenes, Zealots, and a multitude of common folk, each with their own spirit and path.

In the heart of The Jungle lies the truth of man’s nature, a revelation of greed and self-interest that festers deep within. An exposition of souls eager to clutch only at their own desires, blind to the plight of those beneath them. The tale unfolds amid the great ironworks and factories, where the owners and overseers are consumed by the lust to grow their empires vast and unyielding. They care not for the lives crushed beneath the wheels of their progress, their eyes cast only forward, oblivious to the ruin left in their wake. As Sinclair writes, "The line of the buildings stood clear-cut and black against the sky; here and there out of the mass rose the great chimneys, with the river of smoke streaming away to the end of the world." A testament to the pollution pouring forth, an indifference to the harm inflicted upon man and beast alike. The smoke, a river of despair, the waste from the pens a testament to their disregard.

The workers, mere cogs in the relentless machine, toil under the lash of commerce. Their lives weighed against the almighty dollar, their worth less than the coin that buys their labor. "So from the top to bottom the place is simply a seething cauldron of jealousies and hatreds; there is no loyalty or decency anywhere about it, there is no place in it where a man counted for anything against a dollar." The hours are long, the breaks nonexistent, the threat of dismissal without warning a shadow that hovers ever close. In this time, this era of unchecked power, the law offers no shelter. The owners unleash their demands with impunity, the laborers driven faster, the conditions squalid and unforgiving.

No agency stands to offer aid, no voice to call out the injustices. The unions, twisted in their purpose, prey upon the very men they claim to protect. Sinclair’s words cut deep, revealing a population caught in the grip of a merciless machine. "Here is a population, low-class and mostly foreign, hanging always on the verge of starvation and dependent for its opportunities of life upon the whim of men every bit as brutal and unscrupulous as the old-time slave drivers; under such circumstances, immorality is exactly as inevitable, and as prevalent, as it is under the system of chattel slavery." A slavery of a different kind, no less harsh, no less consuming. The men and women of Packingtown, bound to their fate, their lives a testament to the cruelty of unchecked ambition.

In the shadows of a world half-remembered, there lies a poem by Edgar Allan Poe, a piece he held in some esteem, called "Dream-Land." Within its woven lines, the name "Thulé" rises, a specter from both Virgil's pen and a further origin, more recent yet no less ethereal. Virgil spoke of Thulé, a distant isle, a whisper at the edge of the world known to ancient Greeks. Yet Poe, a man drawn to the currents of German thought, found another source, a voice that beckoned from beyond the veil of time. 

There is a tale told by Karl J. Arndt, of Poe's dance with the ghost of Goethe. In Arndt's telling, Poe's verses echo those of Goethe, a mimicry or perhaps a homage. The Oxford Companion whispers of Goethe, a master of words, his Faust a crown of poetic drama, split across the years, the first act in 1808, the second as Goethe himself passed into the shadow in 1832. Amidst this magnum opus lies a sliver of verse, "The King of Thulé," a lament of loss and a goblet heavy with memory. A king bereft, drowning in drink, and at last, casting his last tie to the world into the sea before following it into the abyss.

The king in Poe's "Dream-Land" mirrors this tragic monarch, a shadowy reflection in a world of half-light. Poe, a soul perhaps haunted by loss and the numbing balm of the bottle, saw in this tale a kinship. Less than a year before he penned "The Pit and the Pendulum," he invoked Thule, a word like a talisman, twice in his collected works. In "Dream-Land," Thule bookends the tale, a dark twin to Goethe's king. The landscape painted in Poe's verses is one of desolation, a haunted land where specters of lost friends roam, a realm stripped of color.

Poe's admiration for Goethe, if not directly, was perhaps filtered through his esteem for Tennyson, a poet of great regard. In the echoes of Tennyson's verses, Poe might have heard the refrains of Goethe, a melody carried on the winds of literary creation, in the many iterations that surfaced after the original had been cast into the world. In those lines, the shadow of Thule looms, a place both real and imagined, a bridge between the realms of the living and the dead.

In the quiet aisles of the grocery store, under the indifferent watch of fate and the fluorescent glow of the overhead lights, an applesauce spill lay waiting. A customer might wonder if such an innocuous event could unravel into something larger, something with consequences that stretch beyond the simple act of slipping and falling. For Jennifer Palmer, it did. She found herself entwined in a narrative of negligence and disregard, a tale told not by words but by the actions of a manager who turned a blind eye.

Paul Martin, the manager, had been informed. Once, twice. The applesauce spill was not a secret, hidden in the shadows. Rich Wayne, a dutiful employee, brought it to light at five in the afternoon, and again, Mary J. Haddigan spoke of it. Each time, Martin's response was the same, a dismissive shrug, a preoccupation with his dinner, the mundane over the immediate. By half-past five, Jennifer Palmer lay on the cold, hard floor, her back bearing the brunt of Martin's indifference.

In the courts of California, they speak of malice. Of actions taken with a willful and conscious disregard for the harm they might cause. They speak of despicable acts, of conduct so far removed from the common decency expected of mankind that it demands retribution. Palmer would argue that Martin's knowledge of past injuries, his awareness of the peril the spill posed, should have stirred him to action. Yet, like the indifferent hands of a clock ticking away the minutes, he let the danger persist.

The question was not whether she could claim her due for the injury sustained, but whether she could reach beyond the tangible and claim punitive damages. For in California, to breach an obligation, to act with oppression, fraud, or malice, is to open oneself to the weight of justice. And Martin's actions, or lack thereof, might well be seen as a conscious disregard for the safety of others. As the statute reads, malice might not require intent to harm but merely the willful ignorance of potential harm.

Palmer's tale was not of a single fall, but of a pattern, a series of incidents ignored. In 2009, five slip-and-fall incidents had already marked the history of D&D Markets, and yet, Martin's actions remained unchanged. The narrative of negligence wound through the months, leading inexorably to Palmer's fall. And now, she stood on the precipice of justice, the law as her guide, seeking not just compensation, but a recognition of the wrong inflicted by Martin's callous indifference.

It remains to be seen whether the courts will hear her plea for punitive damages, whether they will see in Martin's actions the malice required by law. But in the gathering shadows of the courtroom, as the echoes of past judgments linger in the air, one thing is clear: the story of Jennifer Palmer and the applesauce spill is more than a simple tale of injury. It is a testament to the power of accountability, a reminder that actions, no matter how small, can have consequences vast and far-reaching. And that justice, though sometimes slow, is relentless in its pursuit.

She had always felt as if there was something she needed, some yearning etched deep within her bones. It was a longing that refused to be quelled, a desire unfulfilled. It began when she was about fourteen, just stepping into the threshold of adolescence, and it lingered still, three years on at the age of seventeen. By now, she had come to know it was not a thing she craved, but a someone. Yet no boy stirred her interest. There were those who had been drawn to her, stumbling through their awkward rituals to charm the uncharmable, but none found her favor. She often questioned herself, pondering this oddity, searching for reasons why such a strange thing would plague a girl her age. Years of contemplation had birthed theories, but none held enough truth for her to dwell upon. So she lived her life, a constant interrogation of her own desires.

Home was a sanctuary of peace. Her parents were gentle folk, calm and untroubled. They never quarreled, not with each other, and seldom with their daughter. The only discord arose from her pursuit of independence, her free spirit clashing against their quietude. She was a daughter born of placid stock, yet she countered their tranquility with her vibrant personality, making her quite likable alongside her inherent kindness.

Today, however, peace was shattered. As she wandered from room to room, seeking fresh inspiration, a short scream pierced the air, her mother's voice, once lovely, now strained. Panic gripped her as she rushed to the kitchen. "Mom?! Mom, what's wrong?!" she cried, breathless. Her mother lay crumpled on the floor, pain etched across her face, each breath an "Ow" escaping her lips. Her daughter knelt beside her, a hand reaching out to offer aid. "Ouch... swee-ty, I... need you to take me to... the hospital." The words came in gasps, squeezed out through the veil of agony. "Okay, Mom, tell me how I can help." Her mother guided her hands, and at that moment, the girl was grateful for the strength she had honed. She lifted her mother, carried her to the car, laid her gently in the backseat, and drove.

The hospital awaited with its scent of antiseptic and fear, a place where sickness held court. Yet she was blind to it all, her mind consumed with the task of aiding her mother. She carried her swiftly, calling out for assistance. Faces, etched with worry, converged around them. A rolling bed appeared, and they laid her mother upon it, wheeling her away for examination. The girl was left alone, seated in the waiting room, consumed by worry.

Her mother had fallen from a stepping stool, reaching for a vase hidden in the highest cabinet, a simple misstep that had brought them here.

In the quiet pursuit of understanding what lay beneath the surface of human frailty, a study set out across the land to uncover the mysteries of the Mediterranean Diet, or the Med diet as it came to be known. Word carried that this way of living, mirrored in a high alternate Mediterranean (aMed) diet score, held promises of guarding against the harsh grasp of chronic heart disease and stroke, and even the shadows of stroke mortality. This aMed diet, a variation upon the Mediterranean theme, spoke of a life rich in the bounty of the earth—plant foods and their proteins, fruits and nuts of the land, grains whole and legumes. It favored the warmth of olive oils over the cold of saturated fats and asked for the creatures of the sea over those of the land. It allowed for modest toasts with wine, for it did not demand asceticism.

The old tales of prior studies whispered of a bond between the Med diet and a lesser burden of death, both total and of the heart. One trial, like an ancient saga, showed this diet more potent than the path of low-fat living, helping shed the weight of flesh and balance the blood's humors. Yet in the past, the focus had not lain upon the specter of stroke or its lethal kin.

This tale followed the journey of 74,886 women, bound by the Nurses' Health Study, wandering from their youth into the autumn of age, with no history of cardiac or diabetic ills. Over two decades, from 1984 to 2004, they bore witness through their own words, self-reported visions of their feasts upon questionnaires designed to capture the essence of their dietary past year by year. In this passage of time, more than ninety-five in a hundred remained steadfast. The tales they told were verified against the hard truth of records and certificates, though some stories, lacking proof, were deemed probable, and so they entered this chronicle—tales of stroke and heart's failure.

To see clearly through the haze of chance, the scholars took the scores from the aMed diet, each a whispered echo of years past, and averaged them, seeking a true reflection of long-term fidelity to this diet. They adjusted for life's many confounding paths: age, the smoke of tobacco, the heaviness of body, the hormonal changes of womanhood, the intake of vitamins and spirits, the vigor of one's leisure, and the use of aspirin.

They employed the tools of Cox proportional-hazard modeling, their way of seeing the unseen threads linking aMed scores to the risk of heart and stroke, separating the fatal from the nonfatal, each type its own story.

In the end, the tale told of women who walked the path of the Mediterranean diet with fidelity, who bore higher aMed scores, and who found themselves less burdened by the specter of heart disease and stroke. Over the span of twenty years, there appeared 2,391 new cases of heart disease, 1,763 strokes, and 1,077 deaths from the silent killer of cardiovascular disease. Those women who stood in the highest quintile of aMed scores faced a lesser risk than those in the lowest, their relative risk a mere 0.71. Thus, the story passed into the annals of time, a testament to the power of the Mediterranean way.

The sign bore the words like a dire whisper from another age. Hitler is alive in Burma. On the corner of the street stood Ellen Page, the actress from Juno, solitary with her placard held aloft. The letters scrawled in Sharpie ink told a tale of unsettling portent. Burma, the land known also as Myanmar, lay in the grip of a brutal militant junta. They had seized power in the year 1962, a coup d’état that cast a long shadow over the nation. The year 2007 saw the streets swell with the first protests in a decade. The monks, clad in robes the color of saffron, led the charge. The Saffron Revolution, they named it, for the hue of their vestments. The populace began to stir, to rise, and the junta soon met them with violence. It was like war. A war waged upon the peaceful, the monasteries stormed by soldiers. Foreign journalists were snatched from the streets, imprisoned. A Japanese photojournalist, Kenji Nagai, fell on September 27th, 2007, a casualty for bearing witness. Official reports spoke of 13 dead, but Colonel Hla Win, an army defector, whispered of a hidden carnage. “The bodies can be counted in several thousand,” he said.

This tale is old as time. Governments, since the dawn of civilization, have sought to crush dissent, to hold dominion over their people. The emperors of Rome claimed divine favor for their reign. In Japan, emperors were seen as gods incarnate, leading their people with technology and ritual, and our own president, George W. Bush, spoke regularly with Ted Haggard, who led the Stupid People Worldwide under the Republic Party’s banner.

Tales of such tyranny are like shadows cast long across history. The June 4th protest of 1989 at Tiananmen Square comes to mind, where students and intellectuals, laborers and visionaries, gathered to defy the government's iron hand. The numbers of the dead are as disparate as the stories told, the Chinese government speaking of hundreds while the Red Cross whispered of thousands more. Then there was Rwanda, in the 1990s, where the Hutu militias, with the government's aid, began their grim work, the systematic slaughter of the Tutsis and any who dared to moderate. And the specter of Hitler's Third Reich, a shadow that fell across nations, a time of terror for those of Jewish descent, speaks of the extremes to which such power can reach.

In the dim corridors of jazz history, the figure of Duke Ellington rises like a shadow cast long by a setting sun. His presence, a subtle whisper behind the keys, speaks less of the man himself and more of the vast tapestry he wove. A tapestry where each thread, each note, each pause, bore the weight of his genius. Ellington, the silent architect, built cathedrals of sound where the voices of his orchestra soared. In the spaces he created, soloists found their freedom, their voices unfurling like banners in the wind. Yet, beyond the improvisations, there lay a precision, a structure woven tight as the skin of a drum, calling forth the specific hues of his band’s timbre to paint his musical visions. His mastery lay not only in the individual notes but in the grand symphony of souls he orchestrated, each player a vital part of the luminous whole. 

The pages of the Grove Music Dictionary speak of Ellington’s sound, his innovation, as they whisper of the Creole Love Call. In this composition, Ellington’s voice, devoid of words, becomes a color, a texture, a spirit inhabiting the air. It is an early testament to his vision, where voices meld with instruments in a dance of sound and silence. The call and response, a dialogue between voice and reeds, unfolds in the slow pulse of a twelve-bar blues. Each chorus, a chapter in a tale told without words, sings with the raw clarity of life itself. The muted trumpet’s lament, the clarinet’s high cry, the full band’s echo—all converge in a crescendo before settling back into the primal call of voice and reeds. Here, the voice growls, an instrument unto itself, before a trombone’s dissonant mutter brings the tale to a close.

In the year that followed, as the world turned and the notes of Hot and Bothered filled the air, Ellington’s genius continued its quiet revolution. The call and response between “Bubber” Miley’s muted trumpet and Baby Cox’s scat singing intertwines, a dialogue of soul and spirit, of flesh and wind. It Don’t Mean a Thing (If It Ain’t Got That Swing) carries this conversation forward, where Joe “Tricky Sam” Nanton’s muted trombone becomes the voice of the earth, grounding the melody in the eternal dance of sound and silence. In these compositions, Ellington’s legacy is not merely heard—it is felt, a pulse beneath the skin, a whisper in the dark.

In the silent corridors of time, where life etches its relentless march, a question lingers like smoke in the hollow of a long-forgotten chamber: why do creatures evolve the way they do? Are there unseen chains that bind and guide the hand of change? D'Arcy Thompson, in the year of 1917, mused upon this and remarked how the language of numbers had yet to capture even the simplest forms that dwell in nature's realm. A sentiment not yet outgrown even by our modern age. Yet, with the passing years, the art of mathematical modeling has been cast upon the spiral shells of mollusks, tracing the lineage of their form through the eons, as Raup and Stanley once did in 1981. Herein, we embark on a journey, a study, to unearth how these mathematical whispers, spoken in the growth and evolution of Prunum, can unravel the mysteries of their becoming. Through the eyes of X-ray, we chart the bones of their shells, setting parameters that the mind might use to dream both of what is and what could be. These numbers find voice in the program CerioShell, a creation of Stone in 1995, conjuring shapes that might dwell within the bounds of what is possible. And alongside these phantoms, experiments and observation weave their tale, seeking to illuminate the grand tapestry of life's change.

A shell, in its essence, is a journey—a tube winding its way through the vast compass of time and space. Each turn, each curve, is a whorl spiraling around an imagined axis, the columella, steadfast and true. The pace of its dance varies, and where each whorl meets its next is marked by a suture, a line of demarcation. In the end, it is the largest whorl, the body whorl, that stands as the crowning chapter of its story. The spire, it is called, all whorls save for the last, with the apex a beacon at its tip and the base its anchor. Through an aperture, the creature within peers out, extending into the world beyond.

These shells, they can be seen from many eyes: apical, basal, apertural, and abapertural. The common gaze is apertural, with the opening toward the eye and the apex reaching skyward.

To count these whorls, one must begin from above, from the apical view. There, the first suture marks the beginning, and from it, a line is drawn to cleave the shell into two. Whorls are tallied from this line, estimated to the quarter of a turn.

A shell, it is a series of doorways, moving through the tapestry of time, as the creature builds its home around itself. One might trace this path, marking the center of each aperture, measuring its breadth and height.

In this dance of creation, numbers are woven, and once the figures are known, the shell's genesis can be altered, its story rewritten in the language of mathematics.

In the dim lands of Indonesia, where the sun sets upon the archipelago and the night gathers close, the little lives of newborns flicker in the shadows, unmoved by the turning years. The tale of their survival, of mothers too, is a story writ in numbers, a litany of promises unmet. The aims of the Millennium, those lofty goals, loom unfulfilled while water runs clean and the earth is washed of its stains. Yet the hearts of mothers and the breaths of babes still falter in their quest for life, their hopes not yet measured against the mark set for them by time’s unyielding hand.

In the villages and towns, where the cries of life begin, there are hands that catch and hands that fail. Seventy-two in a hundred now know the touch of those skilled in the art of life’s beginning, yet still, the old ways linger. The midwives, with their ancient wisdom, cannot stave off the blood’s dark tide when it rises, and so the death of mothers is a sorrow all too known, the loss a testament to what yet needs doing. The numbers speak of progress, yet they lie in their silence, for the work remains unfinished.

The children suffer too, their small bodies wracked by the old foes of water and waste. The healers who once came now come less often, and the care they need after birth is but a shadow, a whisper lost in the wide expanse of this land. The cut that saves, the surgeon’s knife, is a stranger to many, its edge rarely felt. In the cities, it finds its place, yet in the fields, it remains but a rumor, a story told in the hushed voices of women who walk the long road to hope.

And in this place of disparity, where the rich find solace in the arms of medicine, the poor stand outside, their hands empty, their pockets bare. The choice that lies before those who would change this tale is a stark one: to carve out a path for each ailment or to weave a broader tapestry that holds all in its embrace. The allure of focused work is bright, its goals clear and its rewards swift. But the cost is high, for to choose one is to forsake another, and the balance tilts, leaving some in shadow.

In this land of islands, where the sea binds and separates, the question remains: how to care for the mothers and the children, how to bring light to the places where the night has long held sway. It is a question of choices, of paths untaken, of a future yet to be written in the lives of those who wait for the dawn.

In the annals of time stretching back a century, popular music has unfurled into a tapestry so vast and intricate that to name each thread is a fool's errand. The strands of genres—rap, rock, country, jazz, folk—each birthing a multitude of offspring, sub-genres and sub-sub-genres, a lineage unending. Among these, the branch of Heavy Metal stands, a colossus in the realm of popular sound, evolving and shifting over the last four decades into a beast most diverse and expressive. Its voice is a chorus of emotions, a symphony dwelling in the shadows. From its nascent cries, the genre revealed a malleability, a clay in the sculptor's hand, giving rise to myriad forms, each more intricate than the last, until the present where the lines between them blur and fade.

In this modern epoch, the heavy metal landscape is a labyrinth of niches, each with its own tongue and lore, so much so that the essence of metal itself eludes definition. It is an amalgam, a mingling of echoes from distant genres, yet it remains a creation with roots. To grasp the metal that reverberates through today’s halls, one must seek the heart of the metal movement, for it is not merely a genre but a force, a revolution.

Metal, in its essence, is a movement cloaked in shadow. It is a symphony of excess, an anthem of more—more bass, more volume, more fury, more spectacle. A departure from the primitive, it demands skill, mastery, and those who wield it, they possess a prowess that bleeds into the music. Metal is a journey down paths of altered states, a testament to the psychedelic haze of the mid-seventies when minds unfurled and creation knew no bounds, the music transcending into realms unknown, drug-fueled and unapologetic. This was music that embraced the visceral, the dark, a stark contrast to the sunlit melodies that dominated before. The legacy of such darkness finds its roots entwined with the Romantic Era, a time when shadows danced upon the stage of art. The words of songs, like those found in Helter Skelter, speak of this darkness, a descent into chaos that marked the Beatles’ foray into the heavy, a retort to the Rolling Stones, a declaration that they too could walk the paths of shadows.

Thus, the tale of metal unfolds, a narrative of darkness and excess, of mastery and movement, echoing through the corridors of time.

In the years before the Surrealists would lay their visions upon canvas, there was Henri Rousseau, crafting his own dreams with the patience of a man who knew them precious. The Dream, a painting born in 1910 from the hands of this Post-Impressionist, stands as a testament not only to a woman's wonderment at a land conjured in sleep but also to Rousseau’s own longings, the visions that drove his brush. Since he first took up the craft, he sought not just to paint but to be seen, to be welcomed into the fold of artists and those who marveled at their creations. Yet this path was not without its trials, a struggle within his heart, torn between the safety of imitation and the wild, uncharted lands of his own imagination. The Dream is a canvas of this struggle, an embodiment of Rousseau's battle to either mimic the styles that might grant him acceptance in the eyes of the art world's elite or to set forth on his own, carving a path through the thicket of his own creativity.

To ponder The Dream in this light, one must wander back through the story of Rousseau himself. Born on May 21, 1844, in the quiet town of Laval, northwest of France, his life began not with the strokes of a brush but in the hands of his father, a tinsmith by trade, who knew the comforts of a modest prosperity (Shattuck 47). No academies opened their doors to Rousseau in his youth; instead, he toiled for the nation, a gabelou in the toll service, though those who spoke of him often erred, calling him a douanier, a customs inspector (Shattuck 46). The loss of his first wife, Clémence, followed by the deaths of eight of his children, left him with but one daughter, Julia, and a sorrow as deep as the ocean (Shattuck 49). In painting, he sought refuge, a new beginning in the colors and forms that might offer solace. Unlike his contemporaries who painted the peasantry with romantic hues, Rousseau was a folk painter, his dreams as humble and earnest as those of his kin.

To understand Rousseau's yearning for acknowledgment within the art world is to see it for what it was, a natural longing. He was a man who came late to the canvas, untrained by the formalities of art schools, painting in the shadow of giants. It was only as Matisse began to be whispered about in the circles of art that Rousseau felt the first glimmer of recognition. In Modern French Painters, Jan Gordon draws a line between the two—Matisse, who feared nothing more than the mundane in art, and Rousseau, whose dream was to create a work so pleasingly conventional that he might gain entrance to the Artiste Français (92).

In the vast wilderness of thought where the great minds roam, there lies a path that winds between ethics and beauty, truth and their mirrored reflections. Like the words etched upon the ancient urn that Keats once pondered, beauty and truth are intertwined, bound in a dance as old as time itself. We learn much in this life through the schooling of books or the harsh tutelage of experience, yet the appreciation of what is moral and what is beautiful seems innate, a knowledge unspoken and untaught, whispered to us on the winds of existence. These are not matters of dictation but of revelation, a quest to uncover the why behind the art or the act, not the how.

Critics might gather around da Vinci's Mona Lisa, speaking of light and shadow, the stories held within each brushstroke, yet at the heart of it lies an enigma unsolved, a whisper of something beyond words. When one speaks of a cherished tale or a painting that stirs the soul, the explanation often begins with that elusive phrase, "There's just something about it," before reason takes its ponderous course. The essence of art and morality slips through the fingers of analysis, leaving behind a residue of the infinite. As O'Connor so rightly put it, a story is the vessel for what cannot be simply stated, a bridge to the unsayable. The spirit of a tale lingers beyond its telling, just as ethics speaks in silence, transcending the bounds of language. As Wittgenstein mused, ethics dwells in the realm of the transcendental, echoing the same ineffable quality that art possesses.

In the realm of the unseen, where the noumenal lies, as Kant might have described, is where art and morality resonate most deeply within us. These are felt rather than explained, touching us in places where words falter. Literature, with its woven tapestry of words, stands apart, carrying the weight of moral truths like no other art.
